name: Vitamin D3 (Cholecalciferol)
summary: Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) is the animal-derived form of vitamin D, synthesized in the skin from sunlight and commonly used in supplements. It is more effective than D2 in raising and maintaining serum vitamin D levels.
description: Vitamin D3 is a fat-soluble secosteroid that plays a vital role in calcium and phosphate balance, bone mineralization, muscle function, and immune regulation. It is synthesized in the skin upon exposure to ultraviolet B (UVB) light and is also obtained from dietary sources like fatty fish, egg yolks, and fortified foods. Compared to vitamin D2 (ergocalciferol), D3 is more potent and maintains higher serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations. Supplementation with D3 is the preferred choice for preventing and treating deficiency, supporting bone and muscle health, and potentially modulating immune and mood-related conditions.

metadata.natural_source: Sunlight (UVB-induced skin synthesis), fatty fish, liver, egg yolks, fortified foods
metadata.prescription_status: OTC (nutritional doses), prescription (high dose or injectable)

primary_indications: Prevention and treatment of vitamin D deficiency
Adjunctive therapy in osteoporosis and fracture prevention
off_label_uses: Adjunctive support in immune function (respiratory infections, autoimmune disorders)
Fall and fracture prevention in the elderly
contraindications: Granulomatous disorders (e.g., sarcoidosis) with risk of excess conversion to calcitriol

items: Vitamin D deficiency prevention and treatment

sections.text: Vitamin D3 is converted in the liver to 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 (calcidiol), then in the kidney to the biologically active 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (calcitriol). Calcitriol binds to the vitamin D receptor (VDR), regulating genes that control calcium absorption, bone metabolism, and immune responses.

adult.deficiency treatment: 1000–2000 IU/day for maintenance; 50,000 IU weekly for 6–8 weeks in deficiency (under medical supervision)

sections.pediatric: 400–600 IU/day depending on age; deficiency doses individualized by clinician

sections.text: Serum vitamin D levels rise within days to weeks. Full skeletal and immune benefits may take several months of sustained supplementation.

common: Generally well tolerated at recommended doses

other: Avoid excessive doses due to risk of hypercalcemia and toxicity.
Use cautiously in renal disease or granulomatous disorders.

items.risk: Reduced vitamin D metabolism and calcium absorption

items: Renal function in long-term or high-dose therapy

sections.pregnancy: Safe at RDA doses; high doses require medical supervision
sections.lactation: Safe; may improve breast milk vitamin D content
sections.geriatrics: Safe; supplementation recommended due to reduced cutaneous synthesis

sections.text: Not required, but discontinuation may lead to recurrent deficiency if dietary/sunlight exposure is inadequate.

items: Vitamin D3 is more effective than D2 in maintaining serum 25(OH)D levels.
Preferred supplement form for deficiency correction and maintenance.
Deficiency is widespread, especially in higher latitudes, elderly, and individuals with limited sun exposure.
Toxicity occurs mainly with chronic use of >10,000 IU/day, leading to hypercalcemia.
